speaker: [TD NOTE
line: The name on the headstone he hides behind, Alan Smithee, is a well known Hollywood in-joke. It's the name a lot of directors "hide behind" when they have no interest in having their own names attached to the project any more. I honestly *did* know this already but kudos to Autumn T. for pointing it out.]

speaker: MALE VOICE
line: Give it up, Mulder! You've got no chance!

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: Damn it.

speaker: MALE VOICE
line: My sniper zombies are everywhere.

speaker: CIGARETTE SMOKING PONTIFF
line: I'll offer you a deal. You give me the Lazarus bowl and I'll give you Scully.

speaker: RED-HAIRED WOMAN'S VOICE
line: Mulder!

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: How about this deal? You give me Scully, I don't smash the Lazarus bowl and shove the pieces where the Son of God don't shine, you Cigarette-Smoking Mackerel Snapper.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: I break the Lazarus Bowl and all your sniper zombies go back to being good, little, well-behaved corpses.

speaker: CIGARETTE SMOKING PONTIFF
line: You don't fool me, Mulder. That bowl is your Holy Grail. Encoded in its ancient ceramic grooves are the words Jesus spake when he raised Lazarus from the dead-- still capable of raising the dead 2,000 years later. Proof positive of the paranormal. You could no sooner destroy that than let the redhead die.

speaker: RATIONAL ZOMBIE
line: Come on, man. Don't break the bowl. We don't want to go back to being dead. There's no food, no women, no dancing. Save the bowl and we'll dump that Ciggy-Smoking Stooge for you and you'll be the new King of the Dead.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: I'd rather serve in Heaven than rule in Hell. serve in Heaven."] and before they start rolling. That ain't Shandling, I recognize that classic profile anywhere, it's Duchovny!]

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: Is that your flashlight, Mulder, or... you just happy to be lying on top of me? DARRYL ZANUCK THEATER 20TH CENTURY FOX HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: My flashlight.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: Oh, that.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: You know, seven long years I've been waiting for just the right moment, Scully.

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: Oh, you're a sick man, Mulder. Go on. start of this shot. That's Bill Millar who also plays the director of the movie.]

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: I love you, Scully. No ifs, ands or...

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: Bees.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Yesterday, a small pipe bomb ripped through the crypt of Christ's Church here in DC. There were no casualties, no thefts, no note making any demand.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who's taking credit for it?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Nobody.

speaker: MAN
line: SHE: Jodie Foster's foster child on a Payless budget. He's like a... Jehovah's Witness meets Harrison Ford's "Witness."

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, Christ's Church. Isn't that, uh, Cardinal O'Fallon's church?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Yes. O'Fallon's residence is adjacent to the crypt.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who's Cardinal O'Fallon?

speaker: MAN
line: Cardinal "Oh-fallen," perhaps.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Um... He's one of the most powerful men in the church today. His name often comes up as a possibility for the first American pope.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh. I-I don't want to be myopic here, sir, but this looks like a straight up terrorist act for the A.T.F.

speaker: MAN
line: "Myopic."

speaker: SKINNER
line: Yes, it does.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you going to answer your phone?

speaker: MAN
line: Me?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: MAN
line: I didn't want to be rude.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sir, who the hell is this guy?

speaker: MAN
line: Hello?

speaker: SKINNER
line: This is Wayne Federman. He's an old buddy of mine from college. He's a writer out in Hollywood now and he's working on an FBI-based movie. He's asked me to give him access.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A screenwriter?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: It's actually... It's a writer-slash-producer.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's actually just a hindrance-slash-pain in the neck.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Yo, yo, yo. Agent Mulder, I don't want to eat your lunch. I'm just here for some procedural flavor-- just a taste.

speaker: MULDER
line: I've no idea what you just said.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, the Skinman's filled me in on your particular bent.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: He said that you come at things maybe a little fahkatke, a little Star Trekky, which is the exact vibe I'm looking for for this thing I'm doing. It's a Silence of the Lambs meets Greatest Story Ever Told type thing. It's... beautiful, and I will not be in your way. I'll be strictly Heisenbergian-- a hologram.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Mulder, Mr. Federman will accompany you today to Christ's Church where he will act as an observer on this case. You will extend to him every courtesy and protection you would a friend of mine and a friend of the Bureau's. Agent Scully, I require your services here for the morning.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sir, have I pissed you off in a way that's more than normal?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Just curious if she's more than your partner.

speaker: MULDER
line: Enough, Wayne.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Hey, whatever. CHRIST'S CHURCH WASHINGTON, DC distinguished looking priest, CARDINAL O'FALLON. WAYNE FEDERMAN follows them as they walk through the church.)

speaker: MULDER
line: Cardinal O'Fallon can you think of anyone who might make an attempt on your life?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: The church always has enemies, Agent Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: The size of the bomb would have limited its destruction to just the crypt itself. Is there anything down there worth targeting?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Not really. Just some old bones, artifacts, relics... documents that we store down there in the cold. We like to think of it as God's Refrigerator.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: That's a great line.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Thank you.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: "God's Refrigerator."

speaker: MULDER
line: Wayne, shut up.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: No treasures to the outside world. Things of negligible monetary value... but great spiritual value to the church-- ancient devotional texts... and medieval relics.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: How about the Shroud of Turin?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: No, afraid not, but we do have the Bathrobe of St. Peter.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: You're kidding?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Yes, I am.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: That's a good line.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Wayne... Shut up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who comes down to the crypt here?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Only myself. There are a half a mile of catacombs here. I like to walk here during lunch.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: That's where the bomb went off.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, my instinct, Cardinal, is to see this desecration of the dead less as a murder attempt and more as a terrorist act-- a message...

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Uh, this isn't me. I think it's you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Excuse me. That's, uh, that's not me.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Let me check. Not me, either. Can never get reception here.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Would that be St. Jude's cell phone, Cardinal?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. That's Micah Hoffman.

speaker: MULDER
line: Micah Hoffman, Willie Mays, and Frank Serpico. That's my Holy Trinity, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Of course, I'm too young to remember but, uh, wasn't he some kind of a '60s campus radical, like a Jerry Rubin or Mario Savio?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Name a '60s counterculture movement and Micah Hoffman was at or near the center of it. He was one of the original Weathermen. He was the first Yippie. He was a better poet than Ginsburg and he was also the starting shortstop for his Columbia baseball team.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Then in the '70s, didn't he go real low profile?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, right after Altamont. He was never really heard from again.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Aw, the Stones get blamed for everything. I don't get it.

speaker: MULDER
line: This should be it here.

speaker: MULDER
line: What did Skinner want you for this morning?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Just paperwork.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Hmm...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, we should have a warrant.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Hey, it's only the Constitution. No big deal.

speaker: MULDER
line: Wow.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Dis-feng shui.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, sorry to denigrate a third of your Trinity, but, uh, looks like Hoffman was killed by one of his own bombs.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, from Dharma bum to Dharma bomb.

speaker: MULDER
line: I knew, uh, Hoffman was a master potter...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, well, it appears he was a master calligrapher as well. Look, Mulder, they've got gum arabic and sodium hydroxide here. Whoo, these would be used to, uh, to age the ink and the paper prematurely. It's a... it's a forger's trick.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, from counterculture to counterfeiter.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, one more pun and I pull out my gun. Scully, look at that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Christos. Looks like a religious text. Can you read Greek at all?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it's pretty rusty but it looks like some kind of lost Gospel. A gospel of Mary Magdalene, and, uh, an account of Christ's life on Earth after the Resurrection.

speaker: MULDER
line: After?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. It's a heretical text, Mulder-- mythical, I should say, but long rumored to be in existence.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, what would Micah Hoffman be doing with heretical religious texts?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think the question is: What would Hoffman be doing forging them?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: I think the real question, "Agents," is: What might O'Fallon be doing with Hoffman's forgeries?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Don't shoot!

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: I like the way you guys work-- no warrants, no permission, no research. You're like studio executives with guns.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Should I call you Agent Mulder or Mr. Mulder, or, like do you have a nickname or something like that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Shh, shh, shh, shh.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Like Skinman?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Just ignore me.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's that?

speaker: FEDERMAN
line: What the hell was that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sure this place is crawling with rats.

speaker: FEDERMAN
line: Is that supposed to comfort me?]

speaker: MULDER
line: Looks like the same gospel of Mary Scully ID'd over at Hoffman's place.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: So, is this a forgery, or is this the real thing?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, there is no "real" Gospel of Mary, Federman. The, uh, original would be a fake.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: All right, so is this a real fake or a fake fake or...?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Sorry, that's me.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Yes?... No, no, no. No, I can hear you. It's just your voice is...

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: There's like a crackly sound and then I hear a syllab... Stop yelling. Yelling isn't helping the situation....

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmm...

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Just talk. Y-you're breaking up. No, let me call you back. Okay. Yeah, I'm telling you... I'm going through a crypt.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Wow!

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Oh, my... God.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Now, Wayne, I'm sure that it was dark in there and that your eyes were playing tricks on you and you've been influenced by ghost stories and horror movies that take place in crypts and graveyards and you hallucinated this vision of these dancing bones trying to reconstruct this bowl.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: No, I didn't hallucinate. That was mechanical or C.G.I.

speaker: MULDER
line: Federman, that wasn't a movie. That was real life.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: The difference being?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, I have got my flavor here, so I appreciate all your help. I've got a movie to write.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're leaving? You don't want to get to the bottom of this?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Not especially.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you know, sometimes truth can be stranger than fiction.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, fiction is quicker than truth and cheaper. You want my advice? You're both crazy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, why do you say that?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, you're crazy for believing what you believe. And you're crazy for not believing what he believes. I'll leave you with that. Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: I miss him already.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, Mulder, I... I know that Federman's bs-ing you, so I'm really hesitant to mention this, but, um... his story reminds me of the Lazarus Bowl.

speaker: MULDER
line: The Lazarus bowl?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We had this wacky nun in Catholic school-- Sister Callahan-- we used to call her "Sister Spooky" 'cause she would tell us scary stories all the time.

speaker: MULDER
line: Twisted sisters, my kind of nun, you know?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, she would hold up an old piece of wood with a rusty nail in it, and she would say "this is an actual piece of the cross that Christ's wrist was nailed to." Or she'd show us a vial of red liquid and say that it was John the Baptist's blood, or something.

speaker: MULDER
line: She'd be in prison today. You realize that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, she would tell this story of when Jesus raised Lazarus from the dead and she said that there was this old woman who was Lazarus's aunt or something...

speaker: MULDER
line: Lazarus's aunt?

speaker: SCULLY
line: ...who was spinning a clay bowl on a wheel nearby and that Christ's words-- the actual incantation to raise the dead--were recorded in the clay grooves of the pottery just like the way music is recorded into vinyl.

speaker: MULDER
line: You see? It's just not true that you can't get good science at Catholic school. It's a lie.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, Sister Spooky says that, uh... that these words in the clay still have the power to raise the dead just like Jesus raised Lazarus.

speaker: MULDER
line: That is a very cool story coming from you, Scully. I'll have Chuck Burks meet you over at my office see if this clay has Christ's Greatest Hits on it and I'm going... I'm going to go have another audience with Cardinal O'Fallon.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: There's music in the air, Agent Scully. See, everything that exists vibrates and therefore sings. The street, uh, your internal organs, electricity, everything. Here, I'll show you. You see, this is my voice bouncing around in the red here. And all this yellow is ambient sound that we habitually tune out. It's the hum of my hardware, Mulder's porn tapes on pause, the sounds from the street-- everything we hear but we don't know we hear. I can hear it with this machine.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Oh...

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wow.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Who made this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We're not sure. Either a forger by the name of Micah Hoffman or, uh, someone else in the vicinity of Jesus Christ.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Oh... Bazingo-- whoever did it is some kind of musical genius. This clay is vibrating in all the keys at once. It's heavenly.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you translate what it says there for me, please?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Did you recover them from the crypt?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: "And then Jesus took his beloved Mary Magdalene in an embrace, an embrace not of God and woman but of man and woman. And Jesus said to Mary, 'love the body for it is all of the soul that our senses can perceive.'"

speaker: MULDER
line: And how about these?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: These appear to be copies of the original.

speaker: MULDER
line: Or rough drafts.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: How?

speaker: MULDER
line: They're all forgeries, sir. Did you buy these from Micah Hoffman?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: I thought they were real.

speaker: MULDER
line: I can understand that. Hoffman was a master. My partner had them analyzed and they're virtually indistinguishable from the real thing. The paper is authentic, the ink, the hand, the diction-- everything. Hoffman was also an explosives expert. Do you have any idea what he might have been doing with a bomb in the crypt?

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you think of anybody who might have wanted to kill Micah Hoffman?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why were you hiding the documents, sir?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: When Micah came to me... with these, as I then thought, ancient texts and our experts verified them - he exploded a bomb in my heart. The Christ that I'd loved was not the Christ in these texts.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you bought them in order to hide them?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: To keep others from feeling the despair... and the anger that I felt. To protect people from what I can now see they needed no protection from.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why didn't you just destroy the documents yourself?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: I thought they were real. I hated them, I despised them. I would have liked to destroy them, but I couldn't. Is being made a fool of a crime, Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'd be doing life if it were, sir.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, uh, Scully, it's me. Can you horn in on the Hoffman autopsy for me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: I got a feeling Hoffman was dead before he died. He was blackmailing O'Fallon with those forgeries. Maybe O'Fallon retaliated.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, Mulder, this bowl. Your buddy Chuck Burks says that it has properties he's never seen before.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, hold on a second. That's my other line.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, Mulder.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Agent Mulder? It's Wayne Slash Federman out in L.A.

speaker: MULDER
line: I can't really talk about the case, you know.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: That's all right-- Skinman's keeping me in the loop. Listen, who do you see playing you in the movie?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm in the movie?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Well, it's a character loosely based on you. It's more of an amalgamation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, hold on a second, Wayne.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Sister Spooky, I've got to take this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'll call you after the autopsy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks.

speaker: MULDER
line: How about Richard Gere?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Ho! Yeah, okay. Uh, seriously. What if I said to you the name "Garry Shandling"?

speaker: MULDER
line: Wayne, you're breaking up. It sounded like you said "Garry Shandling."

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Garry Shandling signed on to play the amalgamation loosely based on you and Tea Leoni's playing the amalgamation loosely based on your partner, you stud. The movie's called the Lazarus bowl.

speaker: MULDER
line: How do you know about the Lazarus bowl?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: The Skinman. Listen, Shandling and Leoni want to meet you guys... get your flavor-- it's an actor type thing. Come on out to the studio on our dime. We'll make it nice.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, who's... well, then who's going to play Skinner in the movie?

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Richard Gere.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Fracturing of skull and surface abrasions initially consistent with concussive force injuries. I am, uh, now weighing the heart which is relatively normal, although somewhat large.

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN'S CORPSE
line: I'm going to need that when you're done with it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, my God.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who are you?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN'S CORPSE
line: I am who I am.

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN'S CORPSE
line: Ah-ah... Noli me tangere, baby.

speaker: [TD
line: "Noli me tangere" means "Touch me not", from the Bible, John 20:17]

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ow! Damn it!

speaker: MULDER
line: What'd you find, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: In Micah Hoffman's stomach there were traces of red wine and strychnine.

speaker: MULDER
line: Man, oh, manischevitz-- communion wine, I bet.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmm.

speaker: MULDER
line: I bet O'Fallon poisoned Hoffman then placed his body near the explosion to cover his tracks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's possible, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: I could get a warrant for O'Fallon.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: You're the One God living in truth. Through all eternity you live in unapproachable light...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... Let's allow the man some dignity, okay?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: ...to fill your creatures with every blessing and to lead all men to the joyful vision of our life. In our joy we sing to your Holy, holy, holy Lord God of power and might, Heaven and earth are full of your glory. Hosanna in the highest Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest...

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN CRUCIFIED
line: Consummatum est.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Lord Jesus Christ, you said to your apostles: "I leave you in peace, My peace I give you." Look not on our sins.. .

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let's get this over with.

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: ...But on the faith of your church and grant us the peace and unity of your kingdom. Amen.

speaker: MULDER
line: Augustine O'Fallon, you're under arrest for the murder of Micah Hoffman. You have the right to remain silent.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, my God.

speaker: MULDER
line: Anything you say can and will be used against you...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... Do you see what I see?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, I do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that Micah Hoffman?

speaker: CARDINAL O'FALLON
line: Yes, it is.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Misidentification of a corpse and subsequent unrequested autopsy...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir, the dead man looked very much like Micah Hoffman. He had Hoffman's I.D. on him...

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Scully... if I'm carrying Marilyn Monroe's purse do you assume that I slept with J.F.K.?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Mulder, the FBI has always prided itself on the speedy expedition of its cases but this is the first time-- and I hope you're as proud of this as I am-- that we've ever attempted to pursue a murder case where the victim was still alive and healthy.

speaker: MULDER
line: A bomb went off, a crime's been committed. There's a dead body nobody seems to give a damn about, O'Fallon's been less than forthcoming and Hoffman, at the very least is guilty of forgery and extortion.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Mulder, you will leave O'Fallon alone. You will leave Hoffman alone and Agent Scully, you'll put your trigger-happy scalpel away. Best case scenario... you get to keep your jobs. Worst case, O'Fallon and the church bring a huge embarrassing lawsuit against the Bureau which will feature you two as its sacrificial lambs. As of right now... I am forcing you to take a four-week leave effective immediately pending review.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think this whole Richard Gere thing is going to Skinner's head.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We're off this case, Mulder.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Compadres. I teased out something very fabulous from your pottery there.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Layered in under the ambience there. Guess what language that is.

speaker: MULDER
line: Chuck, I've had a bad day.

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: It's a dead language. I had a linguist in here to listen to the recording. It's Aramaic.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's the language that Christ spoke. Did your linguist happen to translate it?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Yes, he did. It's in two parts. The first part here roughly translates as "I am the walrus. I am the walrus. Paul is dead. Coo-coo-ca-choo." Although there is no Aramaic word for "walrus." So it literally says "I am the bearded cow-like sea beast."

speaker: MULDER
line: What's the second part?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: Second part's a little freakier. Here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: CHUCK BURKS
line: It appears to be one man commanding another to rise from the dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Lazarus?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: I am become Jesus Christ.

speaker: MULDER
line: I am become skeptical.

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: There I was totally bumming after Altamont, and I thought throw in the towel and go to law school or continue to fight and become a forger of scandalous religious documents.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I suppose that's a choice every young gifted American male is faced with.

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: I knew O'Fallon from college. He was a divinity professor of mine.

speaker: MULDER
line: At Columbia.

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: Yeah. And he's a decent man but with an overweening pride and sense of responsibility borne of a fundamental lack of respect for the human animal. He believes in God, but not in man, in man's ability to choose, to live in freedom. He has Christ in his brain, but not in his heart.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, uh... you created a Christ in these forgeries that was more suited to your particular world view?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: Yeah. But before I could write like Christ I had to become him in much the same way I imagine an actor who plays a part becomes that part. So I immersed myself in Jesus Christ. Not just the church and teachings but the man, the custom of his time, the language, the vibe, the feeling of Christ.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So why didn't O'Fallon and the Elders go outside the church for authentification?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: Because the forgeries were too damning of the church. They couldn't risk the exposure. But then, something truly weird came over me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Remorse?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: Conversion, Agent Scully. The lightning bolt that transformed Saul to Paul on the road to Damascus. One day I was not just impersonating Jesus Christ, I had become him. That's why I blew up the crypt. The forgeries were blasphemous and needed to be destroyed.

speaker: MULDER
line: How did your cell phone get on the dead man in the crypt?

speaker: MICAH HOFFMAN
line: God works in mysterious ways.

speaker: MULDER AND TV
line: Well, as long as they can think we'll have our problems. But those whom we are using cannot think they are the dead brought to assimilated life by our electrode...

speaker: MULDER
line: It's open.

speaker: MULDER AND TV
line: You know, it's an interesting thing when you consider the earth people who can think......

speaker: MULDER
line: Couldn't sleep either, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Plan 9 From Outer Space?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. It's the Ed Wood investigative method. This movie is so profoundly bad in such a childlike way that it hypnotizes my conscious critical mind and frees up my right brain to make associo-poetic leaps and I started flashing on Hoffman and O'Fallon. How there's this archetypal relationship like Hoffman's Jesus to O'Fallon's Judas or Hoffman's Jesus to O'Fallon's Dostoyevsky's Grand Inquisitor, or Hoffman's Jesus to O'Fallon's St. Paul.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How about Hoffman's Roadrunner to O'Fallon's Wile E. Coyote?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you think it's at all possible that Hoffman is really Jesus Christ?

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you making fun of me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, no, I don't. But crazy people can be very persuasive.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, yes, I know that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe true faith is really a form of insanity.

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you directing that at me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. I'm directing it at myself and at Ed Wood.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you know, even a broken clock is right 730 times a year.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How...?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You've seen this movie 42 times?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Doesn't that make you sad? It makes me sad.

speaker: ACTOR 1
line: You ever been to Hollywood?

speaker: ACTOR 2
line: Oh, a couple of times a few years ago.

speaker: ACTOR 1
line: You're going to be there in the morning. Just a few minutes from Hollywood in the town of San Fernando reports have come in of saucers flying so low...

speaker: MULDER
line: You know, Scully, we've got four weeks probation vacation and nothing to do and Wayne Federman's invited us out to L.A. to watch his movie being filmed and God knows I could use a little sunshine.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: California, here we come.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Agents! I'm so glad you could hang.

speaker: WAYNE FEDERMAN
line: Come on, I want you to meet the people that are going to play you. Garry Shandling, Tea Leoni, this is Agents Mulder and Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nice to meet you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hi.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Nice to meet you.

speaker: TEA LEONI
line: It's a pleasure.

speaker: MULDER
line: Big fan. Fox Mulder.

speaker: TEA LEONI
line: No kidding. Huh.

speaker: TEA LEONI
line: Well, you know, while I've got you here maybe, uh, maybe you could show me how to run in these things.

speaker: TEA LEONI
line: Right over here, I was thinking 'cause, I tell you, I'm having a hell of a time with these heels. What, are they government issue or something? wife, is doing the running. She nearly tripped during filming but ended up receiving a huge round of applause. Very funny scene which I missed the first time 'round as I was too busy watching DD and Garry Shandling.]

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Hey, uh... Uh...

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: How are you? Seriously, listen could I ask you something?

speaker: MULDER
line: Sure.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Uh, do you dress to the left or to the right?

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you... What do you mean?

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Look, when I play a character I need to find his center, his, sort of, rudder, so to say and then everything comes from that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh... I guess mostly to the left.

speaker: [TD
line: Check, it is Blue. Blue's mother appeared in "Ice".]

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: "Mostly"?

speaker: MULDER
line: Most of the time.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Most of the time. To the left.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING
line: Wardrobe!

speaker: WOMAN
line: Rolling!

speaker: SUGAR BEAR
line: And rollando! Come on, now, kick it in the ass and action, zombies!

speaker: ZOMBIE
line: What is this?

speaker: SUGAR BEAR
line: Cut! Go ahead, ruin my career.

speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
line: What seems to be the problem, Mr. Zombie, sir?

speaker: ZOMBIE
line: What the hell is this? What the hell's in my mouth? What's Tea Leoni's shoulder made out of?

speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
line: Uh, craft service, what is Tea Leoni's shoulder made of?

speaker: TINA THE CRAFT SERVICE GIRL
line: Turkey, just like you asked for.

speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
line: Turkey. Ms. Leoni's shoulder's made of turkey.

speaker: ZOMBIE
line: Tofurkey! I asked for tofurkey! I'm a vegetarian! Half the zombies are vegetarian! Oh, my God!

speaker: TOFURKEY ZOMBIE
line: The people are made out of turkey!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hey, Mulder, it's me. What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm, uh, working at the, uh, computer. What are you doing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm, uh, packing. Just, you know, getting ready for our trip back to D.C. tomorrow.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know, Scully, I was just thinking about Lazarus, Ed Wood, and those tofurkey-eating zombies. How come when people come back from the dead they always want to hurt the living?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, that's because people can't really come back from the dead, Mulder. I mean, ghosts and zombies are just projections of our own repressed cannibalistic and sexual fears and desires. They are who we fear that we are at heart-- just mindless automatons who can only kill and eat.

speaker: MULDER
line: Party pooper. Well, I got a new theory. I say that when zombies try to eat people, that's just the first stage. You see, they've just come back from being dead so they're going to do all the things they miss from when they were alive. So, first, they're going to eat, then they're going to drink, then they're going to dance and make love.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, I see. So it's just that we never get to stay with them long enough to see the gentler side of the undead.

speaker: MULDER
line: Exactly.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hold on a second, that's my other line.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello?

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Mulder, it's Assistant Director Skinner. I hope I didn't catch you at a bad time.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, sir, I'm just at the, uh, computer.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Listen, I just wanted to apologize for coming down so hard on you during the Hoffman slash O'Fallon case.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh. I appreciate that, Skinman.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Don't call me that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, sir. Um... Uh, where are you now?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I'm right underneath you. I'm in L.A., at the same hotel as you. Right below you and Agent Scully.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Federman got me an Associate Producer credit on the movie.

speaker: MULDER
line: A.P. Skinner, huh?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh... So what are you up to right now, sir?

speaker: SKINNER
line: I'm taking a bubble bath.

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, hold on just one second, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, Skinman is calling me from a bubble bath.

speaker: SKINNER
line: It's still me, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, sir, well, hold on one second, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, Skinner is calling me from a bubble bath.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wow, he's really gone Hollywood.

speaker: MULDER
line: Totally.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, Mulder, speaking of Hollywood, I think that Tea Leoni has a little crush on you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, yeah, right. Like Tea Leoni's ever going to have a crush on me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think that Shandling likes you a bit, too.

speaker: MULDER
line: Really?

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: I love you, Scully. No ifs, ands or...

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: Bees.

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: Wait, wait, Mulder... I can't.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: I know this feels wrong because we're friends and we treat each other as equals, but...

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: No, no, it's not that. It's not that.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: Well, what then?

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: I'm in love with Assistant Director Walter Skinner.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's it, Scully, I can't take it anymore.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Shh, Mulder, sit down.

speaker: GARRY SHANDLING AS MULDER
line: What does he have that I don't have?

speaker: TEA LEONI AS SCULLY
line: A bigger flashlight.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Been looking all over for you.

speaker: MULDER
line: They got it so wrong, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I got a page from the Washington Bureau. Micah Hoffman was murdered tonight. Murdered in his own home by Cardinal O'Fallon who then hanged himself. A murder-suicide.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's Jesus and Judas, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wow... It's all over now.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, it's just beginning. Hoffman and O'Fallon were these complicated, flawed, beautiful people and now they'll just be remembered as jokes because of this movie. The character based on O'Fallon is listed in the credits as "Cigarette-Smoking Pontiff." How silly is that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Pretty silly.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, what about us? How are we going to be remembered now 'cause of this movie?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, hopefully, the movie will tank.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about all the dead people who are forever silent and can't tell their stories anymore? They're all going to have to rely on Hollywood to show the future how we lived and it'll all become... oversimplified and trivialized and Cigarette-Smoking Pontificized and become as plastic and meaningless as this stupid plastic Lazarus Bowl.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think the dead are beyond caring what people think about them. Hopefully we can adopt the same attitude. You do know that there aren't real dead people out there, right? That this is a movie set?

speaker: MULDER
line: The dead are everywhere, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... We're alive. And we're relatively young and Skinner was so tickled by the movie..

speaker: MULDER
line: I bet he was...

speaker: SCULLY
line: That he has given us a Bureau credit card to use for the evening.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Come on.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I have something to confess.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm in love with Associate Producer Walter Skinner.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah... Me, too.
